extracted_key_facts: The "Years of Lead" in Morocco spanned from 1956 to 1999.
Morocco gained independence in 1956, leading to a power struggle between the Monarchist Movement and the Popular Movement.
Hasan II marginalized the Popular Movement after his enthronement in 1961 and legitimized state violence.
State-sponsored violence during the Years of Lead included elimination of opponents, kidnapping, torture, and extrajudicial executions.
Many official and secret prisons, as well as clandestine torture locations, were constructed during the Years of Lead.
Progressive intellectuals, human rights advocates, and leftist activists opposing the regime disappeared.
Human rights organizations such as AMDH, UNEM, AI, and IER refer to the period between 1956 and 1999 as the "Years of Lead."
The Years of Lead are characterized by political repression and state actions outside the bounds of law.
There is no consensus on the precise start date of the Years of Lead; some place it in 1956, others in 1958 with the Rif revolt suppression, and others during Hasan II's reign (1961-1999).
The Rif revolt (1958-1959) was suppressed with aerial bombardment led by French officers and supervised by Prince Muley al-Hasan ben Muhammad, resulting in thousands of Riffian deaths.
The IER documented 20,046 cases of repression, detention, torture, disappearance, and murder between 1956 and 1999.
Secret detention and torture centers existed, including Dar al-Mouqri, Complexe in Rabat, Derb Moulay Chrif in Casablanca, Courbis in Casablanca, Tagounite in Ouarzazate, and Dar Bricha in Tetuán.
Clandestine prisons built during the Years of Lead included Agdez in Ouarzazate, Tazmamart in Errachidia, Kalaat M´Gouna, and Skoura in Ouarzazate.
Ahmed Boukhari estimates 300 kidnappings between 1960 and 1973, excluding thousands of disappearances.

Several cases of disappeared individuals are documented, including Abdel Haq Rouissi (disappeared in 1964), Bab Allah Belaïd (kidnapped in 1964), Kassim Al-Haous (died under torture in 1970), Al-Houcine al-Manouzy (disappeared in 1972), Belkassem Wazzan (kidnapped in 1973), and others.
Agents of Cab. I assassinated members of the Moroccan National Movement between 1956 and 1960.
Mehdi Ben Barka, a leader of the UNFP, was kidnapped and murdered in Paris on October 29, 1965.
Mohammed Lahrizi, along with his wife and daughter, were murdered in 1962 under orders from General Ahmed Dlimi.
The regime carried out extrajudicial executions, including of those involved in the 1971 Skhirat coup attempt.
The regime persecuted progressive and leftist activists, including members of Ilā l-Amām and the Movimiento del 23 de Marzo, and members of unions and human rights organizations.
Repression of protests included the killing of 50 demonstrators in Casablanca in 1965 and 114 in Casablanca in 1981.
Magazines and cultural initiatives critical of the regime were prohibited, including Souﬄes-Anfās in 1972 and several others in 1984.
Newspapers critical of the regime were shut down, such as al-Mu#arrir in 1981 and al-Masār in 1988.
Many intellectuals, unionists, and leftist activists fled Morocco between 1971 and 1995 as political refugees.
The fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989 and the dissolution of the Soviet Union reduced the perceived threat of socialist movements.

extracted_key_facts: Alejandro Viana was born in Ponteareas, Spain, in 1877 and died in Mexico City in 1952.
Viana was a Republican politician and businessman in Vigo, Spain, before the Spanish Civil War.
After the fall of the Spanish Republic in 1939, Viana went into exile in France.
Viana was appointed head of the Emigration Service of SERE (Servicio de Evacuación de Republicanos Españoles) in Paris in April 1939, responsible for organizing the evacuation of Spanish refugees.
Viana organized 18 expeditions to Mexico and Chile between April and August 1939, evacuating almost 8,000 refugees.
In August 1939, Viana resigned from SERE due to disagreements, but continued to support refugees through the Sociedades Hispanas Confederadas.
After France fell to the Nazis, Viana fled Paris to Bordeaux, where he continued to assist refugees.
Viana was targeted for kidnapping by the Gestapo and the Spanish Falange in Bordeaux.
Viana escaped to La Louvesc in the unoccupied zone of France.
In 1941, Viana embarked on the 'Alsina' from Marseille, aiming for Buenos Aires with other refugees.
The 'Alsina' was stopped in Dakar, Senegal, for five months due to lack of British authorization to cross the Atlantic.
The passengers of the 'Alsina', including Viana, were transferred to Casablanca, Morocco, in June 1941.
Viana and other refugees were interned in a concentration camp in Casablanca before being released following diplomatic interventions.
Viana eventually boarded the 'Quanza' from Casablanca and arrived in Veracruz, Mexico, in November 1941.
Viana purchased a pharmacy in Mexico City and lived there until his death in 1952.
The Franco regime sought Viana's extradition from France, but it was ultimately unsuccessful.
During his time in Casablanca, Viana worked to ensure the embarkation of the refugees onto the Quanza.
The Quanza arrived in Veracruz, Mexico, on November 18, 1941, allowing Viana to attain political asylum
